Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO)-A Change Detection Array in the Pacific Arctic Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Arctic is changing. The Distributed Biological Observatory studies these changes in the northern Bering and Chukchi seas. Investigators sample locations that are biologically important in U.S. territorial waters. These locations have been sampled annually since 2010. Other investigators also sample the same locations. As a result, the locations are sampled multiple times a year. Data are collected on environmental conditions including water column and sea floor animals that are food for whales, seals, and birds. Data are shared internationally. The project contributes to the U.S. National Ocean Policy and Interagency Arctic Research Policy Committee 5-year plan. The data will be of value to U.S. and international science and management agencies, private industry, and local communities as they try to understand changes to the environment. The project supports three graduate students.

The observational plan includes standard hydrographic and biological measurements along five transect lines located in the northern Bering and Chukchi Seas. These sampling locations are arrayed south-to-north and reflect a gradient of seasonal sea ice change and seawater warming. The investigators chose these 5 regions because they are zones of high biological productivity and biodiversity. Results so far indicate a freshening and warming of Pacific seawater which transits northward over the spring to fall season. These changes have impacted prey for larger marine mammals and seabirds. Satellite observations are also used to evaluate seasonal changes in sea ice concentration, surface seawater temperature, and chlorophyll concentration. The biological measurements focus on lower trophic levels and shipboard surveys of upper trophic level organisms. This research will increase our understanding of the impact of key environmental forcing parameters on biological change in the system. The collection of key prey-predator biological data along with physical and chemical measurements will allow for analyses and ecosystem modeling which will promote better understanding of Arctic environmental changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding biological responses to rapidly changing sea ice cover and water column properties in the Pacific Arctic Region (PAR) requires sampling in a collaborative manner across multiple spatial and temporal scales using both dedicated and opportunistic sampling platforms. The Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO) approach represents an unprecedented and transformative opportunity for coordinated national and international observations of the effects of climate change in the Pacific-influenced Arctic. With the rapid pace of these changes, such as the dramatic lack of ice in winter 2018 in the DBO1 region in the northern Bering Sea, the DBO is in many ways a flagship example of an arctic observing system appropriate in scale and approach for the complexities associated with ecosystem responses to climate change. We leveraged both national and international interest and existing projects to occupy transects for select hydrographic and biological measurements, including a specific focus on upper trophic organism predator-prey relationships. Continuation of the DBO within the SAON activity of the Arctic Council, which will facilitate further development of the international observing pan-Arctic network, including our example of a standard DBO parameter file for data archiving for both nationally and internationally shared data sets. DBO data can also provide a means to test developing conceptual models, such as the Arctic Marine Pulses (AMP) conceptual model, which depicts seasonal biophysical ‘pulses’ across a latitudinal gradient. This conceptual model links processes in four previously-defined contiguous ecological domains for the PAR, particularly a pelagic-benthic coupling model and an advective model.

The DBO was established as a latitudinal “change detection” array extending from the northern Bering Sea across the Chukchi Sea shelf to the Beaufort Sea with sampling both by national and international programs in 2010. Standard DBO sampling included temperature and salinity measurements, currents, chlorophyll a and nutrient measurements, chromophoric dissolved organic matter (CDOM), suspended particulate matter (SPM), optical profiles, phytoplankton, zooplankton and macrobenthic species composition, abundance and biomass measurements as well as seabird and marine mammal observations. Ongoing core support through NSF provides funding for the annual July DBO cruise with Canadian colleagues through Canada’s Three Oceans (C3O)/DBO joint study. 

The DBO project is a contribution to the US-led AON that facilitates both national and international efforts for evaluating ecosystem impacts from high latitude climate change. All DBO data sets collected during the Sir Wilfrid Laurier cruises and many other DBO affiliated projects were submitted to the Arctic Data Center (ADC), along with DBO parameter (metadata) files. DBO data have been used by collaborators for peer-reviewed publications in a nearly completed DSRII DBO special issue. PIs have made multiple presentations at national and international scientific meetings on the DBO network and data, including four DBO data workshops. The sharing of these data has enabled collaborative papers and joint field studies to be coordinated among a number of foreign institutions, with greatly increased synergies. Direct student participation and training at Clark University has included four Ph.D. students, five M.S. students, and seven undergraduates. This research has also facilitated the development of course content in graduate seminars and undergraduate courses.
